mn7:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn7:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the bhikkhus,
mn7:2.1: “Suppose, bhikkhus, there was a cloth that was soiled and dirty.
mn7:2.2: No matter what dye the dyer applied—whether blue or yellow or red or magenta—it would look poorly dyed and impure in color.
mn7:2.4: Because of the impurity of the cloth.
mn7:2.5: In the same way, when the mind is defiled, a bad destiny is to be expected.
mn7:2.6: Suppose there was a cloth that was pure and clean.
mn7:2.7: No matter what dye the dyer applied—whether blue or yellow or red or magenta—it would look well dyed and pure in color.
mn7:2.9: Because of the purity of the cloth.
mn7:2.10: In the same way, when the mind isn’t defiled, a good destiny is to be expected.
mn7:3.1: And what are the defilements of the mind?
mn7:3.2: Longing and immoral greed, aversion, anger, resentment, denigration, contentiousness, jealousy, stinginess, deceit, deviousness, obstinacy, insolence, conceit, arrogance, indulgence, and carelessness are defilements of the mind.
mn7:4.1: A bhikkhu who understands that longing and immoral greed are defilements of the mind gives them up.
mn7:4.2: A bhikkhu who understands that aversion …
mn7:4.30: …carelessness is a defilement of the mind gives it up.
mn7:5.1: When he has understood these defilements of the mind
mn7:5.2: for what they are, and has given them up,
mn7:5.32: He has absolute confidence in the Buddha:
mn7:5.33: ‘That Blessed One is an Arahant, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
mn7:6.1: He has absolute confidence in the Dhamma:
mn7:6.2: ‘The Dhamma is well explained by the Buddha—presently evident, not involving time, verifiable, and goading-on, to be experienced by sensible people for themselves.’
mn7:7.1: He has absolute confidence in the Saṅgha:
mn7:7.2: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, upright, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individuals. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings, worthy of hospitality, worthy of donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’
mn7:8.1: When a bhikkhu has discarded, eliminated, released, given up, and relinquished to this extent, thinking, ‘I have absolute confidence in the Buddha …
mn7:10.1: the Saṅgha,’ he realizes the Dhamma and its meaning, and gains gladness connected with the Dhamma.
mn7:11.1: Thinking: ‘I have discarded, eliminated, released, given up, and relinquished to this extent,’ he realizes the Dhamma and its meaning, and gains gladness connected with the Dhamma.
mn7:11.2: When he’s glad, joy is born. When the mind is joyous, the body becomes calm. When the body is calm, he feels at ease. When he’s at ease, the mind becomes composed.
mn7:12.1: When a bhikkhu of such virtue, such qualities, and such understanding eats boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, that is no obstacle for him.
mn7:12.2: Compare with cloth that is soiled and dirty; it can be made pure and clean by pure water. Or unrefined gold, which can be made pure and bright by a forge.
mn7:12.3: In the same way, when a bhikkhu of such virtue, such qualities, and such understanding eats boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, that is no obstacle for him.
mn7:13.1: He abides having pervaded with a mind of friendliness the first direction, likewise second, likewise third, likewise the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, he abides having pervaded the whole world with a mind of friendliness—abundant, expansive, immeasurable, free of enmity and aversion.
mn7:14.1: He abides having pervaded with a mind of compassion the first direction, likewise the second, likewise the third, likewise the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, he abides having pervaded the whole world with a mind of compassion—abundant, expansive, immeasurable, free of enmity and aversion.
mn7:15.1: He abides having pervaded with a mind of contentment the first direction, likewise the second, likewise the third, likewise the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, he abides having pervaded the whole world with a mind of contentment—abundant, expansive, immeasurable, free of enmity and aversion.
mn7:16.1: He abides having pervaded with a mind of equanimity the first direction, likewise the second, likewise the third, likewise the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, he abides having pervaded the whole world with a mind of equanimity—abundant, expansive, immeasurable, free of enmity and aversion.
mn7:17.1: He understands: ‘There is this, there is what is inferior to this, there is what is more refined than this, and there is an escape beyond this scope of perception.’
mn7:18.1: Knowing and seeing like this, his mind is liberated from the influxes of sensuality, being, and ignorance.
mn7:18.2: When it’s liberated, he knows it’s liberated.
mn7:18.3: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the renunciate life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there will be no more of this.’
mn7:18.5: a bhikkhu who is bathed with the inner bathing.”
mn7:19.1: Now at that time the brahmin Sundarikabhāradvāja was sitting not far from the Buddha.
mn7:19.3: “But does Master Gotama go to the river Bāhuka to bathe?”
mn7:19.4: “Brahmin, why go to the river Bāhuka?
mn7:19.5: What can the river Bāhuka do?”
mn7:19.6: “Many people deem that the river Bāhukā leads to a heavenly world and bestows merit. And many people wash off their bad actions in the river Bāhukā.”
mn7:20.1: Then the Buddha addressed Sundarikabhāradvāja in verse:
mn7:20.3: at Gayā and the Sundarikā too,
mn7:20.6: a fool can constantly plunge into them
mn7:20.7: but it won’t purify their dark actions.
mn7:20.9: What the Payāga or the Bāhukā?
mn7:20.10: They can’t cleanse a cruel and criminal person
mn7:20.12: For one who is pure it’s always
mn7:20.13: the spring festival or the sabbath.
mn7:20.14: For one who is pure, clean of action,
mn7:20.15: their vows will always be fulfilled.
mn7:20.16: It’s here alone that you should bathe, brahmin,
mn7:20.17: making yourself a sanctuary for all beings.
mn7:20.18: And if you speak no lies,
mn7:20.21: and you’re faithful and not stingy:
mn7:20.22: what’s the point of going to Gayā?
mn7:20.23: For any well may be your Gayā!”
mn7:21.1: When he had spoken, the brahmin Sundarikabhāradvāja said to the Buddha,
mn7:21.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyesight can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
mn7:21.4: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha of bhikkhus.
mn7:21.5: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the ascetic Gotama’s presence?”
mn7:22.1: And the brahmin Sundarikabhāradvāja received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
mn7:22.2: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, abiding alone, withdrawn, heedful, diligent, and resolute, lived having entered upon the supreme goal of the renunciate life for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness, having for himself comprehended and realized it right in the present experience.
mn7:22.3: He understood: “Birth is destroyed; the renunciate life has been lived; what had to be done has been done; there will be no more of this.”
mn7:22.4: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the Arahants.
